Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: You think you can ride?  Then today's your lucky day.

Speaker: bloodied carrier
Dialogue: Bethlehem says...

Speaker: bloodied carrier
Dialogue: ... he's... headed north. He's gonna kill ten people in every town. Then burn it to the ground. For what you did...

Speaker: bloodied carrier
Dialogue: He said to tell you Pine View's on his way. He said he'd wait there, but not for long.  I was so scared, sir... I thought they were going to kill me, too... I wish they would have...

Speaker: postman's pov
Dialogue: Pine View in flames. The big John Deere gun has blown several gaps into the palisade. Bethlehem watches as his army sacks the town. The people have been rounded up. The selection of the ten has begun.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: What are you going to do?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I'm going to stop this.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: You can't.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Get out of my way, Ford. All of you.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: They'll kill you.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Goddamnit --

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: You can't help them!

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: There's still time, Ford!

Speaker: ponytail
Dialogue: You're hurting him.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: No, this is all my doing.    I went against your orders.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: The Holnists we killed. You told me to bury them. But I didn't. I sent Bethlehem the bodies.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Why?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Because Bethlehem has to know that we're not going to stop.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: God damn you, Ford. Those people down there are dying because of us. Because of what we did.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Bullshit. They're dying because of Bethlehem. They're dying because this is a shitty world. And if we're ever going to change it, then somebody might have to die. If I could make it be me down there I would. But I can't.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: My God, what have I done?  We don't even know their names...

Speaker: ponytail
Dialogue: We know their names. The little one's my brother. His name is Billy.

Speaker: ponytail
Dialogue: What Ford did was wrong. But it doesn't change anything for any of us. Does it?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: He's out there somewhere. Watching. I can feel it.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: You feel it too, don't you? Didn't have to end like this, Sheriff. He knew where I'd be if he wanted to face me like a man. Instead, he's hiding like a rabbit. So much for your Postman.

Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: Ready!    Aim!

Speaker: briscoe
Dialogue: Ride, Postman! Ride! You hear me? I said ride!

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Fire!

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Ford thinks you're going to do something.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I am.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: If I don't, those kids are going to keep on getting themselves killed.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Ford doesn't know what it means to be a kid. He doesn't have your memories. None of them do. All they've got is the lousy world we gave them. And this is the only decent thing in it.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: What? Being a postman? It's all bullshit, Abby. All of it.  I took this uniform off a skeleton to stay warm. I made up the rest to stay fed. There is no restored United States.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: I knew it was something like that.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Weird thing is, being a Postman was almost the best thing that ever happened to me...  Remember this? You left it behind that night.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: I remember...

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I always liked to think you left it on purpose. But maybe you just forgot it.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Is this everybody?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: The rest are on the overdue list.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: This is everybody.  Got a letter from President Starkey.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: 'Greetings all carriers.'

Speaker: carriers
Dialogue: Greetings, President Starkey!

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: 'I've been in contact with The Postman. I've received all the reports. I'm proud of you all.'

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: In dark days, in a weary world, you gave everything and asked for nothing. You beat back despair and replaced it with hope and for that your country can never repay you. But the price is too high. I won't see anymore of my bravest die. It is my duty to hereby disband the Postal Service of the restored United States. You are to burn your uniforms and The Postman is to return to Minneapolis at once. Thank you and that is all.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: The President never wrote that letter.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: If he could've that's what he would have said.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Who's the other letter to?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Bethlehem. I'm taking it to him in the morning.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: What does it say?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Mail's private. You know that.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: What does it say?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: It says it's over. It says we quit.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: It says you quit. What about the oath?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Tell me something, Ford. How much mail can a dead postman deliver? It's over.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Then I'll take it.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I can't trust you.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: If this is the end. If this is the last piece of mail that ever gets delivered. I'll take it.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Whoever takes this letter probably dies for it.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: I'm still a postman. You owe it to me... I owe it to me.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I'm going to St. Rose, Abby. And I'm taking you with me. I know you don't want to hear it, but that's my child inside you. I want to see it born somewhere safe. I have a right to that, Abby. Whether you like it or not.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Thought I recognized you.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: General Bethlehem said...  ... You should be on your knees when I do it.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I don't give a damn what that asshole said.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: The general is a great man.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: The general is a fucking lunatic.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: You don't own a thought in that goddamn head of yours, do you?  You want to see a man?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: That's a man.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: You don't understand, do you? You never will until you can think for yourself and be willing to pay the price for it.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: You ready?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: You're a better man than Bethlehem, Luke. I've seen it.

Speaker: chubby
Dialogue: Guess Minneapolis is that way.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: We can't help you. We're just as lost as you are.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Good lord, what do we have here?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: I'm a representative of the restored United States --

Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: He's got a letter. Says The Postman sent it.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: A letter?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: 'Bethlehem. This letter is my testimony to the fact that there is no restored United States and there is no Postal Service.'  'My carriers are returning home. In exchange, I'm asking you to let them be. The Postman.'

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: He expects me to believe this?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Traitor...

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Then I've won.     I've won.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: You were supposed to kill him.

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: I couldn't get close enough.  This one's his second in command.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Why doesn't that surprise me?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Bring out the one we found yesterday. They can die together.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Who are you?

Speaker: cal carrier
Dialogue: Name's Clark. Postal Carrier of the restored Republic of California. Who are you?

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Postmaster Ford Lincoln Mercury.

Speaker: cali carrier
Dialogue: It's an honor.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Wait a minute... wait a minute!

Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: Sir?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Hold your fire! You don't know each other?  This will never be over. It'll go on except I'll be fighting a goddamn ghost.

Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: Should we fire, sir?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: No goddamnit.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: No, I won't fight a ghost. Tabula rasa, gentlemen. A clean slate. I want all mail carriers hunted down. I want The Postman found. I want him dealt with.  He rode west?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I don't know him. Do you?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Where do you think he came from?

Speaker: squatter
Dialogue: Howdy. Welcome to sunny California.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: What happened here?

Speaker: squatter
Dialogue: Little accident. The ground started to shake big time and the Hanford nuclear plant went...  ... 'Poof.' Destroyed everything for miles. But the sunsets are beautiful.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: You ever hear of a city called St. Rose?

Speaker: squatter
Dialogue: Friend, I've never heard of St. Shit.

Speaker: squatter
Dialogue: Hey, don't go! I got Monopoly in the house! Boardwalk, Park Place and the Reading Railroad!

Speaker: chubby
Dialogue: You think that's President Starkey?

Speaker: ponytail
Dialogue: No.

Speaker: chubby
Dialogue: What makes you so sure?

Speaker: ponytail
Dialogue: President lives in a white house. That guy's place is gray.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: We can rest in there.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Did you see that?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: I'm hungry, Postman.

Speaker: guard
Dialogue: Set the rifle on the ground.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: This old thing? It isn't even loaded. Where are we?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I know you.     You're famous.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: We will be. Right now, we'd just appreciate some food.  I got some kids behind me, too.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Three.  Hey, guys, come on in! I know you're out there!

Speaker: chubby sentry
Dialogue: Boy, is he smart...

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Thanks.    She's not my wife.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Let me ask you something, have you ever heard of a town with electric lights?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Yeah!

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: How far?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: You seem like a decent man. And these seem like decent people.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: And this seems like a safe place.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: All of them. I'll give you the horses and my gear. Abby's special. She's strong. Probably end up running the place.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: You never heard of a postman?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: There used to be a postman for every street in America. They wore uniforms. And hats. Like this one...

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: My postman knew the name of every kid on my street. He knew our birthdays. He'd even find the baseballs you'd hit down the street. I can still see the smile on his face. The tip of his cap -- when he had a letter in his bag with my name on it. Mine always came just after school. You could set your watch by him. Unless you were waiting on something special -- like a present from somewhere far away or a letter from your sweetheart. Then it seemed like he'd never come. I used to think they could make time stand still.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: I don't think we ever really understood what they meant to us until they were gone. Getting a letter made you feel like you were part of something bigger than yourself. No place was ever too far away for the postman. So nobody ever had to be alone. The postman was someone you could count on. Things just made more sense when they were around.  That's the kind of world we used to have. A world a lot of us took for granted. And now we've got this one. And it makes me wonder -- what kind of world do I want my child to live in? I want my child to live in a world where hopes and dreams aren't just lies you tell yourself to get through another day. I want my child, and I want my friends -- I want all of us to live in a world where you still get your mail.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Yes.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Yeah, I guess I am. And all of a sudden, I'm not wearing the right clothes.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I'm sorry I've brought this on you.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: The order was to burn all uniforms.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: You know what to do then?

Speaker: ponytail
Dialogue: Talk to the people. Gather who's willing. Tell them it's important. Tell them we can make a difference.

Speaker: chubby sentry
Dialogue: And tell 'em we're going to kick ass.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Yeah, tell them that, too.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: This is hard for me.  I don't know why I've been so blessed. And I've tried to find a way to be thankful, but I swear, if I lose you...

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Abby, do you think a lie can become the truth?

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: I don't know, but I believe in you. You have a gift, Postman.     I saw it back in Pine View.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: When you come back, we'll be waiting here for you. So you can take us to St. Rose.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: How do I stop --

Speaker: counterweight
Dialogue: Plummeting into the Columbia River Gorge.      The Mayor lets out a rebel yell.

Speaker: basket
Dialogue: The Postman is whipped along, past the riders below.     The speed exhilarating.

Speaker: old george
Dialogue: Steady, boys, steady.

Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: In accordance with Law Eight...

Speaker: old george
Dialogue: Get on with it, you floppy-eared sonuvabitch!

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Riding over the crest. Galloping toward them. Behind him, forty new mail carriers. All riding like mad. One of them carries the flag of the restored United States.  Gibbs and his men run for their horses. SHOTS are FIRED. Four Holnists go down. The rest gallop away.  The Postman and his carriers meet.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: How many?

Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: A least a hundred. With guns.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: With guns? Are you sure?

Speaker: gibbs
Dialogue: Yes, sir...

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Looks more like two hundred to me...

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Only thing worse than a coward is one who can't count. Lieutenant, do yourself a favor. Die well in this battle. In my army a deserter's life is a brief and unpleasant one.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: At last, someone with courage enough to bring the fight to me.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Reckoning, gentlemen. This is the day I've dreamed of.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: They're an eager-looking bunch. Morale's a dangerous thing.  Bring him up. I want this postman to see how the game is played.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Stay here. No one moves until I give the orders.

Speaker: sergeant
Dialogue: Are they surrendering?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: God, I hope not.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: My little shipping clerk.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: We're both a couple of frauds. You know it; I know it.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Great men are made by other great men. Patton had Rommel. Grant had Lee. But I get you.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Are you trying to goad me into a fight?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Wouldn't it be great if wars could be fought just by the assholes who started them? We could settle this thing right here. You and me.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Unfortunately, it doesn't work that way.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: It does in your army.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I invoke law seven of the Laws of Eight! Any man may challenge for leadership of the clan!

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: What?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I challenge you.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: You're not a Holnist. You're not a member of the clan. You don't have the right.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I have every right. I invoke law seven!

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I challenge for leadership of the clan!

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Where do I know you from?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: 'Cry Havoc! And let slip the dogs of war.' Remember that?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Shakespeare. The one who didn't want to fight.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I should've found a way to kill you then. But you seemed so strong.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Law seven it is.  This war is settled here!

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: I study people. I know your problem. Do you know why you can't fight?

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: You have nothing to fight for. You don't care about anything. You don't value anything. You don't believe in anything. That's what makes me better.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: I believe in the United States Postal Service.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Neither snow...  Will stay this courier from the swift completion of his appointed rounds...

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: It doesn't have to be this way. We don't have to kill each other. We can live together. We can --

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Law three.   Mercy is for the weak.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Ford, don't...

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Law eight. There is only one penalty and that penalty is death.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: He isn't worth it. I'm the head of the clan now! There are going to be new laws!  Law one! No more killing! There's going to be peace!

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Who else?   Who else has a law?

Speaker: woman
Dialogue: Everyone has to learn how to read.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: That's law two. Who else?!

Speaker: luke
Dialogue: Four.    No more tattoos.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: How about it, Ford Lincoln Mercury? You give us law eight.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Be a leader, Ford.

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: Law eight...

Speaker: ford
Dialogue: ... Live and let live.

Speaker: bethlehem
Dialogue: Would I had bestowed that time in the tongues that I have in fencing, dancing and bear-baiting. Oh, had I but followed the arts...

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Grow like savages -- as soldiers will -- that nothing do but mediate on blood.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Somebody take a letter.

Speaker: chubby
Dialogue: Huh?

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: A letter...

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Your daddy wrote to tell you that he'll be here as soon as he can. And that he loves you very much.

Speaker: the postman
Dialogue: Mail's slow.   I'll have to see about that.

Speaker: abby
Dialogue: Your daughter.     Her name is Hope.

Speaker: hope
Dialogue: But he never did see St. Rose. There was too much to be done. He'd made a promise and in keeping it -- he traded one dream for another. With no regrets. And so, in honor of my father...

Speaker: older man
Dialogue: That was me.
